{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} [[File:Ashes Urn 1921.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The Ashes urn in 1921 when it was still owned by Lord Darnley (Ivo Bligh).]]
'''The Ashes urn''' is a small [[urn]] made of [[terracotta]] and standing 11 cm high, believed to contain the ashes of a burnt [[bail (cricket)|cricket bail]]. It was presented to [[Ivo Bligh, 8th Earl of Darnley|Ivo Bligh]], the captain of the [[England cricket team]], as a personal gift after a friendly match hosted at [[Rupertswood]] mansion in [[Sunbury, Victoria|Sunbury]] during the [[English cricket team in Australia in 1882–83|1882–83 tour in Australia]]. After his death the urn was presented to the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]], which has it on display at [[Lord's]] cricket ground in London. The urn has come to be strongly associated with '[[The Ashes]]', the prize for which England and [[Australia cricket team|Australia]] are said to compete in [[Test cricket|Test series]] between the two countries.
==The origin of the urn== [[File:DeathofEnglishCricket.jpg|thumb|The death notice that appeared in ''[[The Sporting Times]]'']] [[File:English cricket team 1883.jpg|left|thumb|200px|An etching of the English cricket team that toured Australia in 1882-83 in the Australasian newspaper of 1882.]] [[File:The Ashes English Team 1883.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The English Cricket Team that toured Australia in 1882-83. They were captained by Ivo Bligh. Standing: William Barnes, Frederick Morley, Charles Thomas Studd, George Frederick Vernon, Charles Frederick Henry Leslie. Centre Row: George Browne Studd, Edward Ferdinando Sutton Tylecote, Ivo Bligh (captain), Allan Gibson Steel, Walter William Read. Front Row: Richard Gorton Barlow, Willie Bates.]] On 29 August 1882 Australia defeated England in a cricket match played at [[The Oval|Kennington Oval]], [[London]]. There was a great deal of dismay felt by the English about this loss and a few days later a mock obituary notice written by [[Reginald Shirley Brooks]] appeared in the [[The Sporting Times|Sporting Times]] which read:
"In affectionate remembrance of English Cricket which died at the Oval on 29 August 1882. Deeply lamented by a large circle of sorrowing friends and acquaintances. RIP. NB. The body will be cremated and the ashes taken to Australia."<ref>The Sporting Times, 31 August 1882.</ref> It was the first time the term 'the ashes' had been mentioned.
It had previously been arranged that a cricket team captained by [[Ivo Bligh, 8th Earl of Darnley|Ivo Bligh]] would tour Australia in 1882-83 and this team became the English hope of victory. Before leaving England for Australia, Bligh pledged to bring back "The Ashes of English cricket".<ref>Melbourne Cricket Club, 2006 “In Affectionate Remembrance: The Story of the Mythical Ashes”. page 19.</ref>
Three main Test matches were played. The first was in [[Melbourne]] and was won by [[Australia]]. The second was also in Melbourne and won by the English. The third match was in [[Sydney]] and was again won by the English. After this it was generally acknowledged that the English were the victors.
After the conclusion of the Test series, a match was played in Sydney in which a United Australian Eleven defeated The Hon. Ivo Bligh's Eleven by four wickets.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-page1415649 The International Cricket Match. England v. United Australia] ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', 22 February 1883, p. 10, at [[National Library of Australia#Trove|Trove]]</ref> This seems to have given rise in Melbourne to some debate about whether it should have counted as a Fourth Test.<ref>Melbourne Cricket Club, 2006 “In Affectionate Remembrance: The Story of the Mythical Ashes”. pages 24-27</ref> However, ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' made it very clear that this game was not part of the international "rubber" which had in fact been won by England.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13529090 Cricket. The International Matches] ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', 22 February 1883, p. 11, at [[National Library of Australia#Trove|Trove]]</ref> There were also other matches played between the English and the individual State cricket teams over the tour.
The urn was made during the 1882-83 tour. It is a very small red terracotta artefact which some believe could be a perfume bottle. Two labels are pasted on it: the top label says "The Ashes"; the lower label is a verse cut out from ''[[Melbourne Punch]]'' magazine of 1 February 1883 which reads:
:''"When Ivo goes back with the urn, the urn;'' :''[[Studd brothers|Studds]], [[A. G. Steel|Steel]], [[Walter Read|Read]] and [[Edward Tylecote|Tylecote]] return, return;'' :''The welkin will ring loud,'' :''The great crowd will feel proud,'' :''Seeing [[Dick Barlow|Barlow]] and [[Billy Bates|Bates]] with the urn, the urn;'' :''And the rest coming home with the urn.''"
These names are some of the men in the English team. Many of them are shown in the pictures above.
There is also an associated red velvet bag with a Victor’s Olive Crown embroidered on it in yellow silk cotton with the emblem “1883” in the middle of it. This bag was made by Mrs Anne Fletcher, wife of the [[John Walter Fletcher|manager]] of the NSW team, in early 1883.<ref>Melbourne Cricket Club, 2006 “In Affectionate Remembrance: The Story of the Mythical Ashes”. page 75.</ref>
==The presentation of the urn== [[File:Lady Janet Clarke circa 1880.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Janet Clarke|Janet, Lady Clarke]], was one of the women who presented the urn to Bligh.]] [[File:Rupertswood circa 1890.jpg|left|thumb|250px|[[Rupertswood]], where the Ashes urn originated]] [[File:Florence Morphy 3.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Florence Morphy (later Lady Darnley) who also presented the Ashes urn to Bligh.]] [[File:Ivo Bligh circa 1890.jpg|left|thumb|150px|Ivo Bligh (later Lord Darnley) who was the recipient of the Ashes urn.]] Reports have established that the estate of [[Rupertswood]] in [[Sunbury, Victoria]] is the birthplace of the Ashes urn legend. According to a 1908 newspaper report in the ''Hobart Mercury'', an unnamed writer from the ''Westminster Gazette'' recalled that a group of Melbourne ladies which included [[Janet Clarke|Janet, Lady Clarke]], and [[Florence Bligh, Countess of Darnley|Florence Morphy]], presented "a tiny silver urn, containing what they termed 'the ashes of Australian (''sic'') cricket.'"<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article12673335 Cricket] ''[[The Mercury (Hobart)|Hobart Mercury]]'', 4 June 1908, p.8, at [[National Library of Australia#Trove|Trove]]</ref> to [[Ivo Bligh, 8th Earl of Darnley|The Hon. Ivo Bligh]], captain of the English touring team after one of the three Tests in 1882-83.
Rupertswood was the home of [[Sir William Clarke, 1st Baronet|Sir William Clarke]] and [[Janet Clarke|Janet, Lady Clarke]]. Sir William was president of the [[Melbourne Cricket Club]]. At Christmas 1882 and again at Easter 1883, the members of the English cricket team were his guests.<ref>Munns, Joy 1994 "Beyond Reasonable Doubt: The Birthplace of the Ashes", pages 16-17.</ref>
A divergent story about the presentation of the urn is that on Christmas Eve, prior to the start of the three-test series, and after a friendly match between the English cricketers and a combination of staff and guests held at Rupertswood, the urn was presented by Lady Clarke to Bligh in a joking fashion.<ref>Munns, Joy 1994 "Beyond Reasonable Doubt: The Birthplace of the Ashes", page 17</ref> Also present on this occasion was the Clarkes' music teacher, Florence Morphy, who was later to marry Ivo Bligh.
There has been some disagreement with this version of events mainly because of three issues. Firstly the verse on the urn was not published in Punch until 1 February 1883 which is five weeks after the Christmas event. Secondly there are statements by both Lord Darnley and Lady Darnley that the presentation happened sometime after the Third Test.<ref>Lord Darnley’s statement is in Cricket Field, 30 June 1894. Lady Darnley’s statement was given to Lady Mildred Allsop and quoted in Munns, Joy 1994 "Beyond Reasonable Doubt: The Birthplace of the Ashes", page 62</ref> The Third Test finished in Sydney on 30 January 1883. Thirdly the accompanying red velvet bag made by Mrs Anne Fletcher, was not made until early 1883.
Joy Munns has taken these problems into account and has concluded that there were two quite separate presentations of the same urn. It was presented firstly at Rupertswood at Christmas and was merely the perpetuation of a joke. The second and most documented event was at Easter (which was around 25 March 1883) at Rupertswood after all the formal matches had finished. On this occasion Joy Munns says the verse was pasted on the urn, it was placed in the red velvet bag and given to Bligh.<ref>Munns, Joy 1994 "Beyond Reasonable Doubt: The Birthplace of the Ashes", page 65.</ref> Lady Clarke and Florence Morphy were both present on this occasion. This version of the presentation being in late March is supported by a statement made by Lord Darnley who said in 1921 that he was presented with the urn by "some ladies of Melbourne after the final defeat of his team".<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article66512851?searchTerm="cobham hall" urn&searchLimits=l-decade=192 International Cricket: The Ashes] ''[[Geraldton Guardian]]'', 15 February 1921, page 1, at [[National Library of Australia#Trove|Trove]]</ref> England in fact won the series 2-1.<ref name="http">{{cite web |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/154318.html |title=England in Australia, 1882–83|publisher=[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack|Wisden]]|accessdate=5 February 2008}}</ref> Bligh's 'final defeat' refers to a non-Test game in Melbourne on 12 March 1883 when they were defeated by the Victorian cricket team in the last formal match of the tour.<ref>Melbourne Cricket Club, 2006 "In Affectionate Remembrance: The Story of the Mythical Ashes". page 28.</ref>
Over Easter many of the English team were guests at Rupertswood and did not embark on the return voyage to England until 29 March. Ivo Bligh stayed for another five weeks during which time it is believed he became engaged to Florence Morphy. He sailed for England on 5 May but returned to Australia in February 1884. Four days after his arrival, on 9 February,<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63185850 Summary of Events] ''[[The Illustrated Australian News]]'', 20 February 1884, (foot of column 2) at [[National Library of Australia#Trove|Trove]]</ref> he married Florence at St Mary's Church in Sunbury.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article93148475 Marriage of the Hon. Ivo Bligh] ''[[The South Australian Chronicle]]'', 23 February 1884, (reproducing original report in ''[[The Argus (Melbourne)]]'' of 12 February 1884) at [[National Library of Australia#Trove|Trove]]</ref> The wedding breakfast was a very lavish affair at Rupertswood.<ref>Melbourne Cricket Club, 2006 “In Affectionate Remembrance: The Story of the Mythical Ashes”. page 29.</ref>
==The urn after Rupertswood== [[File:Cobham Hall 1904.jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[Cobham Hall]] circa 1904. This was where the Ashes urn was kept until about 1927.]] [[File:Ashes Urn January 1929.jpg|left|thumb|200px|The Ashes urn in 1929 when it was in the Long Room of the [[Lord's]] Pavilion.]] [[File:The Ashes Urn Replica (2016).jpg|150px|thumb|right|A modern-day replica of the Ashes Urn]] After their honeymoon in [[Australia]] the couple went to [[England]] in August 1884 where they stayed at [[Cobham Hall]] in [[Kent]]. The English papers reported that Florence was warmly welcomed by the Bligh family on her arrival.<ref>Traralgon Record and Morwell, Mirboo, Toongabbie, Heyfield, Tyers and Callignee Advertiser (Traralgon, Victoria), 29 August 1884 p. 4. http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71545607?searchTerm=ivo bligh &searchLimits=l-decade=188|||l-year=1884</ref> They remained in England for the next 18 months and then returned to Melbourne in January 1886. It was reported at this time that they intended to stay in [[Australia]] for about one year because of Ivo Bligh’s health.<ref>Northern Star (Lismore, NSW ) 17 March 1886, p. 3</ref>
In [[Melbourne]] they lived in a house called Hazelwell in Powlett St East Melbourne and in November 1886 Florence had her first child.<ref>The Australasian Sketcher with Pen and Pencil (Melbourne), 4 November 1886. http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63225550?searchTerm=hazelwell melbourne&searchLimits=</ref> In March 1887 the couple returned to England<ref>The Mercury (Hobart) 11 June 1887. Online reference http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article9134921?searchTerm=ivo bligh&searchLimits=l-decade=188|||l-year=1887</ref> and for some time lived at Cobham Hall.<ref>England Census 1891.</ref> In 1890 Bligh had a position in the wine merchant firm of Morgan Brothers.<ref>Australian Town and Country Journal (NSW) 18 January 1890 p 38. http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71106705?searchTerm="ivo bligh"&searchLimits=l-decade=189</ref>
In 1900 after the death of his brother Bligh became the Earl of Darnley and inherited [[Cobham Hall]]. The Ashes urn remained at the Hall until Bligh’s death in 1927.
Lord Darnley had an interview in 1921 with Montague Grover, a well-known Australian journalist, at his home in Cobham Hall. Grover says that the urn was kept in Darnley’s den where all his other treasured cricket memorabilia were placed. He had numerous photos of the other team players on the wall as well as a leather-bound copy of the original account of the 1882-83 cricket tour of Australia.<ref>Geraldton Guardian 15 February 1921, page 1. Online reference http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article66512851?searchTerm="cobham hall" urn&searchLimits=l-decade=192</ref>
After Bligh’s death Florence presented the urn to the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] in 1929. It was placed in the [[Long Room]] at the Lord’s Pavilion until 1953, when it was transferred to the Cricket Museum next to the Pavilion. A photo of the urn in the Long Room in 1929 is shown at the left.
After the urn was first displayed at Lord's it produced a gradual change in the public perception of 'The Ashes'. In 1933 it was displayed in the National Sporting Trophies Exhibition in London with some of the world’s great sporting memorabilia. To the public the urn was becoming the image and symbol of 'The Ashes'.<ref>Melbourne Cricket Club, 2006 "In Affectionate Remembrance: The Story of the Mythical Ashes". page 82.</ref>
It was not until after about 1950 that the cricket books and paraphernalia almost exclusively used representation of the urn to depict 'The Ashes'. From about 1989 images of the Australian Test cricketers with replicas of the urn appeared in the media.
Since 1929 the urn has returned to [[Australia]] only twice – once when it was brought to Sydney for the Bicentenary Test Match in 1988 and secondly in 2006 for the tour of the Ashes Exhibition to each state capital of Australia.<ref>Melbourne Cricket Club, 2006 "In Affectionate Remembrance: The Story of the Mythical Ashes". page 35.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== [http://www.heritageaustralia.com.au/downloads/pdfs/Heritage%200306_Clarkes%20Rupertswood.pdf From Ambition to Ashes: The Clarkes of Rupertswood]. ''Australian Heritage'', June 2003, pp 41–47.
[[Category:The Ashes]] [[Category:Sports trophies and awards]]

'''Thomas Lyte''' is an luxury English brand, specialising in gold and silverware, sporting trophies and leather accessories.<ref name="Jack"/><ref name="Madslien"/>
The company has designed, made or restored many well known trophies and medals, such as the football’s [[FA Cup]], golf’s [[Ryder Cup]] and rugby’s [[RBS 6 Nations]] and Webb Ellis [[Rugby World Cup]] and the [[Louis Vuitton]] [[America's Cup]] Challenger Playoff Trophy.<ref name="Madslien"/><ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3266990/Wayne-Rooney-presented-golden-boot-Sir-Bobby-Charlton-Wembley-nation-s-time-goalscorer.html Daily Mail: Wayne Rooney presented with golden boot by Sir Bobby Charlton]</ref><ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/wayne-rooney-presented-golden-boot-6605634 The Mirror: Wayne Rooney presented with golden boot to mark all-time England goalscoring record]</ref><ref>[http://www.thefa.com/news/england/2015/oct/wayne-rooney-top-scorer-golden-boot#MTkVTaDmeU0m26K8.99 Golden boot for England's top goalscorer Wayne Rooney]</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-27405196 BBC News Bill Wilson: FA Cup reborn for 2014 final as new trophy is cast]</ref><ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2629384/Arsenal-Hull-chance-lift-brand-new-FA-Cup.html Mail Online: REVEALED: Arsenal and Hull will be playing for a BRAND NEW FA Cup... only the third trophy in more than 100 years of magic]</ref><ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/fa-cup-final-2014-watch-3550166 The Mirror: Watch behind-the-scenes footage as brand new FA Cup trophy is made ahead of Saturday's final]</ref><ref>[http://www.rbs6nations.com/en/news/27206.php#.VQ6cTsZa_wz RBS 6 Nations unveil new trophy]</ref>
==Royal Warrant Holders==
In January 2015; [[Elizabeth II]] appointed a [[Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)|Royal Warrant]] to Thomas Lyte as [[Goldsmith|Goldsmiths]] and [[Silversmith|Silversmiths]]. Granted for a five year period to the firm and founder Kevin Baker Esquire as a grantee, the appointment recognises that Thomas Lyte has been a direct supplier and restorer of silverware to the [[Royal Household]] since 2010.
==History and heritage==
Thomas Lyte was founded by Kevin Baker in 2007.<ref name="Jack">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22213850 BBC Radio 4: Friday Boss - business presenter Simon Jack interviews Kevin Baker, chief executive, Thomas Lyte]</ref>
Its products are designed and created in the company’s London-based leather atelier and silversmith workshop.<ref name="Jack"/><ref name="Madslien">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-20759536 BBC News Jorn Madslien - In pictures: Thomas Lyte sporting trophy workshop]</ref> Thomas Lyte is named after the [[Lyte Jewel]], which was made by miniaturist [[Nicholas Hilliard]].<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/t/the_lyte_jewel.aspx British Museum: The Lyte Jewell]</ref>
==The Football Association Charity Shield==
In 2016, Thomas Lyte restored and rebuilt the Football Association's original 1908 Charity Shield, the replacement of which is known as the [[FA Community Shield]], to mark 50 years since England Captain [[Bobby Moore]] and his teammates beat West Germany in the [[1966 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/fa-charity-shield-to-be-auctioned-off-to-raise-money-for-the-bobby-moore-fund-a3350661.html: Evening Standard: FA Charity Shield to be auctioned off to raise money for the Bobby Moore Fund]</ref>
The trophy raised £40,000 at auction on 10 October 2016, in aid of the Bobby Moore Fund for [[Cancer Research UK]], which was set up by the footballer's widow Stephanie Moore to fund research into bowel cancer, after her husband lost his battle with the disease in 1993. The auction was held at The [[Royal Garden Hotel]] in [[Kensington]], where the England team celebrated the 1966 victory. The Bobby Moore Fund became the FA's new charity partner in July 2016.<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/news/thefa/2016/jul/bobby-moore-fund-becomes-charity-partner-290716: The FA's new official charity partner is Bobby Moore Fund]</ref>
==List of trophies & Awards== * [[Killik Cup]] * The [[European Rugby Challenge Cup]] * The [[European Rugby Champions Cup]] * The [[FA Cup]] trophy * [[Women's Rugby World Cup]] * [[International Champions Cup]] * World [[Speedway Grand Prix]] * Barclays [[ATP World Tour]] Doubles trophy * The [[OFC Women's Nations Cup]] * The [[FA Women's Cup]] * [[Davis Cup]] * [[Fed Cup]] * The [[Emperor's Cup]] for the All-Japan Soccer Championship Tournament * [[Rugby World Cup]] - Webb Ellis Trophy * [[PIPA Snow Polo World Cup Tour]] 2014 trophy * [[Auld Alliance Trophy]] * [[Anglo-Welsh Cup]] trophy * [[North American Soccer League]] 2013 Spring Championship trophy * [[The Ryder Cup]] * Summoner's Cup for [[League of Legends World Championship]] * The [[Melrose Cup]] * [[EDF Energy Trophy]] * Powergen [[Anglo-Welsh Cup]] * [[AFC Asian Cup]] trophy * [[FIBA Basketball World Cup]] trophy (Naismith Trophy)
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{about||the modern headwear known as a "tuque"|Knit cap|other uses|Toque (disambiguation)}} {{use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} [[Image:Portrait of Philip II of Spain by Sofonisba Anguissola - 002b.jpg|right|thumb|King [[Philip II of Spain]], wearing the Spanish ''Tocado'', late 1500s. Painting by [[Sofonisba Anguissola]].]] A '''toque''' ({{IPAc-en|t|oʊ|k}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/toque|title=the definition of toque|website=Dictionary.com}}</ref> or {{IPAc-en|t|ɒ|k}}) is a type of [[hat]] with a narrow [[Brim (hat)|brim]] or no brim at all.<ref name="merriam">{{cite web | url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/toque | title=Definition of Toque | accessdate=11 January 2014}}</ref>
Toques were popular from the 13th to the 16th century in Europe, especially France. The mode was revived in the 1930s. Now it is primarily known as the traditional headgear for professional [[cook (profession)|cooks]], except in Canada where the term is primarily used for [[knit cap]]s.<ref name="merriam" /> [[File:Woman's Toque LACMA M.64.85.6.jpg|thumb|Woman's toque from England, c. 1860 at the collection of [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]]]]
== Etymology == The word has been known in English since 1505. It came through the [[Medieval]] [[French language|French]] toque (15th century), presumably by the way of the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''toca'' "woman's headdress", from Arabic *''taqa'' 'طاقة' for "opening".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=toque | title=toque (n.) | publisher=Etymonline.com | accessdate=11 January 2014}}</ref> and "طاقية" "taqia" for "hat" originally for something "round" that has an opening.
The word toque is [[Breton language|Breton]] for "hat". The spelling with the "que" is Middle Breton, and Modern Breton is spelled tok. Old Breton spells the word toc. The word was borrowed into the French language both for the chef's uniform and the knit cap. [[File:Dolores del Río1.jpg|thumb|[[Dolores Del Rio]] wearing a toque, 1933]]
==Usage== [[File:Handkolorerad modeplasch från mars 1800. Damerna bär toquer, påsliknande mössor utan brätten - Nordiska Museet - NMA.0032520.jpg|thumb|Fashion drawing from 1800 with ladies wearing toques.]] [[File:Tasseled toque of Yo-San silk and chenille embroidery 1917.png|thumb|Tasseled toque from 1917 New York.]] ===Culinary=== {{see also|Chef's uniform}} [[Image:William Orpen Le Chef de l'Hôtel Chatham, Paris.jpg|thumb|''Le Chef de l'Hôtel Chatham, Paris'' (c. 1921), [[oil on canvas]] by [[William Orpen]]]] A '''''toque blanche''''' ([[French language|French]] for "white hat"), often shortened to toque, is a tall, round, pleated, starched white hat worn by [[chef]]s.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://blogmybrain.com/scrabble-word-finder/word/toque.htm | title=Definitions for: Toque | accessdate=11 January 2014}}</ref>
The toque most likely originated as the result of the gradual evolution of head coverings worn by cooks throughout the centuries.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KUdYAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&dq=toque+head+coverings | title=So, You Want to Be a Chef?: How to Get Started in the World of Culinary Arts | publisher= [[Simon & Schuster]] | author= Bedell, Jane | year=2013 | page=69 | isbn=1582704368}}</ref> Their roots are sometimes traced to the ''casque à meche'' (stocking cap) worn by 18th-century French chefs. The colour of the ''casque à meche'' denoted the rank of the wearer. Boucher, the personal chef of the French statesman [[Talleyrand]], was the first to insist on white toques for sanitary reasons.
The modern toque is popularly believed to have originated with the French chef [[Marie-Antoine Carême]] (1784–1833), who stiffened the ''casque à meche'' with cardboard<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/30/magazine/who-made-that-chefs-toque.html|title=Who Made That Chef’s Toque?|first=Daniel|last=Engber|date=28 March 2014|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> <!-- and [[Auguste Escoffier]] (1846–1935) -->.
===Judicial=== * A toque, or sometimes touge, was the traditional headgear of various French [[magistrate]]s. * A low type in black velvet, called ''[[mortar board|mortier]]'' (also rendered in English as [[mortarboard]]), was used by the ''[[président à mortier]]'', president of a ''[[parlement]]'' (the royal highest court in a French province), and of the members of two of the highest central courts, ''[[Court of Cassation (France)|cour de cassation]]'' and ''[[Cour des Comptes|cour des comptes]]''. * A red toque is sometimes worn by German judges, primarily by justices on the [[Federal Constitutional Court]].
===Academic=== The pleated, low, round hat worn in French universities{{spaced ndash}} the equivalent of the [[mortarboard]] or [[tam (cap)|tam]] at British and American universities{{spaced ndash}} is also called a toque.
===Heraldic=== {{unreferenced section|date=December 2013}} In the [[Napoleonic era]], the French first empire replaced the [[coronet]]s of traditional ("royal") [[heraldry]] with a rigorously standardized system (as other respects of "Napoleonic" [[coats of arms]]) of toques, reflecting the rank of the bearer. Thus a Napoleonic [[duke]] used a toque with seven [[ostrich]] feathers and three [[lambrequin]]s, a [[count]] a toque with five feathers and two lambrequins, a [[baron]] three feathers and one lambrequin, a [[knight]] only one ostrich feather (see [[Nobility of the First French Empire]]).
===Athletic=== Toque is also used for a hard-type hat or [[helmet]], worn for riding, especially in [[equestrianism|equestrian]] sports, often black and covered with black [[velvet]].
===Canadian=== {{main|Knit cap}} [[File:RS Wearing a Toque.jpg|thumb|Man wearing a tuque.]] In [[Canadian English|Canada]], ''[[tuque]]'' {{IPAc-en|t|uː|k}} is the common name for a knitted winter hat, or [[watch cap]] (sometimes called a beanie in other parts of the world); the spelling "touque", although not recognized by the [[Canadian Oxford Dictionary]], is also sometimes seen in written English.<ref>http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/thousands-vote-on-correct-spelling-of-canadian-knit-cap-1.2457737, CBC News: Thousands vote on correct spelling of Canadian knit cap, Retrieved Dec. 22, 2015.</ref> The [[Canadian English|Canadian-English]] term was assimilated from [[Canadian French language|Canadian-French]] ''[[wikt:tuque#French|tuque]]''. ''Toque'' first appeared in writing around 1870.<ref>"toque" and "tuque" in Katherine Barber, ed. (2004), ''The Canadian Oxford Dictionary'' (2nd ed.), Don Mills, Ontario: [[Oxford University Press]], {{ISBN|0-19-541816-6}}.</ref><ref>"[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/tuque tuque]" at Dictionary.com.</ref><ref>"[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/toque toque]" and "[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/tuque tuque]" at Merriam–Webster Online.</ref>
The fashion is said to have originated with the ''[[coureurs de bois]]'', French and [[Métis]] fur traders, who kept their woollen nightcaps on for warmth during cold winter days. Such hats are known in other English-speaking countries by a variety of names, including ''beanie'', ''watch cap'' or ''stocking cap''; the terms ''tuque'' and ''toque'' are unique to Canada and northern areas of the United States close to the [[Canada–United States border]]. {{clear}}
==See also== {{portal|Fashion}} *[[Kalimavkion]] *[[Skufia]] *[[Taqiyah (cap)]] * [[Tam (women's hat)|Tam]] * [[List of headgear]]
{{clear}}

==External links== *[http://www.heraldica.org/topics/france/ Index to French Heraldry]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} [[File:Lukova building.jpg|thumb|300px|Ski resort [[Jasná]] in Central [[Slovakia]]]] A '''winter sport''' or '''winter activity''' is a recreational activity or [[sport]] which is played on snow or ice.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chambersharrap.co.uk/chambers/features/chref/chref.py/main?query=winter+sports&title=21st|title=winter sports, noun|work=Chambers 21st Century Dictionary|accessdate=22 February 2010}}</ref> Most such sports are variations of [[skiing]], [[ice skating]] and [[sledding]]. Traditionally such sports were only played in cold areas during [[winter]], but [[artificial snow]] and [[artificial ice]] allow more flexibility. Artificial ice can be used to provide [[ice rink]]s for [[ice skating]], [[ice hockey]] and [[bandy]] in a milder climate.
Common individual sports include [[cross-country skiing]], [[Alpine skiing]], [[snowboarding]], [[ski jumping]], [[speed skating]], [[figure skating]], [[luge]], [[skeleton (sport)|skeleton]], [[bobsleigh]] and [[Snowmobile|snowmobiling]]. Common team sports include [[ice hockey]], [[curling]] and [[bandy]]. Based on the number of participants, ice hockey is by far the world's most popular winter sport, followed by bandy.<ref>[http://www.worldbandy.com/newspost_7640.html ]</ref> Winter sports often have their own multi-sport tournaments, such as the [[Winter Olympic Games]].
==History== Snow and ice during the wintertime has led to other means of transportation, such as sledges, skis and skates. This also led to different pastimes and sports being developed in the winter season as compared to other times of the year. Naturally, winter sports are more popular in countries with longer winter seasons.
While most winter sports are played outside, ice hockey, speed skating and to some extent bandy have moved indoors starting in the mid-20th century. Indoor [[ice rink]]s with [[artificial ice]] allow [[ice skating]] and [[hockey]] to be played in hot climates.
==List of winter sports== '''''Note''''': the Olympic rings next to a sport indicates that this particular sport is included in the [[Winter Olympic Games]], as of the [[2014 Winter Olympics]] in Sochi. The Paralympic logo indicates the same for a sport not in the Olympics but in the [[Winter Paralympic Games]].
===[[Ice skating]]=== * [[Figure skating]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Short-track speed skating]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Speed skating]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]]
===[[Skiing]]=== [[File:Skier-carving-a-turn.jpg|thumb|Skiing]] [[Image:Jeremy Teela 2002 Olympics.jpg|thumb|right|United States biathlete [[Jeremy Teela]] at the [[2002 Winter Olympics]].]] * [[Ski Ballet|Acroski (No longer part of the winter olympics)]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Alpine skiing]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Biathlon]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Cross-country skiing]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Freestyle skiing]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Kite skiing]] * [[Mogul skiing]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Monoskiing]] * [[Newschool skiing]] * [[Nordic combined]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Modern competitive archery#Ski archery|Ski archery]] * [[Skiboarding]] * [[Skibob]] * [[Skijoring]] * [[Ski jumping]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Snowkiting]] * [[Speed skiing]] * [[Speed riding]] * [[Telemark skiing]] * [[Winter pentathlon]]
===[[Sledding]]=== [[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-09740-0004, Oberhof, II. Wintersportmeisterschaften, Bobfahren.jpg|thumb|right|An East German bobsleigh in 1951, [[Oberhof bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton track|Oberhof track]], Germany]] Sports that use sleds going down ice tracks or pulled by something: * [[Bobsled]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Dogsled racing]] * [[Ice blocking]] * [[Luge]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Skeleton (sport)|Skeleton]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Wok racing]]
===[[Snowboarding]]=== * [[Alpine snowboarding]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Boardercross]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Snowboard|Slalom]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Snowskate|Snowskating]] * [[Slopestyle]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]]
===[[Snowmobile|Snowmobiling]]=== [[File:SnowmobilesYellowstone.jpg|thumb|A snowmobile tour at [[Yellowstone National Park]].]] * Free style * [[Snocross]] * Recreation * Cross-country * Hill climbing
===[[Team sports]]=== [[File:Bandy in Medeu Kazakhstan.JPG|thumb|Based on the number of participating athletes, bandy is the second most popular winter sport in the world]] * [[Bandy]] * [[Broomball]] * [[Curling]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Ice hockey]] [[File:Olympic rings with white rims.svg|28px]] * [[Ice sledge hockey]] [[File:IPC logo (2004).svg|24px]] * [[Ice stock sport]] * [[Military patrol]] * [[Ringette]] * [[Rink bandy]] * [[Snow rugby]] * [[Snow snake]] * [[Synchronized skating]] * [[Yukigassen]] (competitive [[snowball fight]])
===Other sports=== * [[Ice climbing]] * [[Ice racing]] * [[Ice speedway]] * [[Snowbiking]] * [[Ice canoeing]] * [[Cold-weather biking]] * [[Drifting (motorsport)|Snow drifting]] * [[Cross country running]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.athleticsweekly.com/0/admin/blog/cross-country-for-the-winter-olympics/|title=Cross country for the Winter Olympics|access-date=26 July 2016}}</ref>
===Recreational sports=== [[File:Bonhomme de neige (MuseumBellerive).JPG|thumb|Snowman]] Some 'sports' are competed (or simply enjoyed) on a more casual basis, often by children: * Building [[snowmen]] * Building [[snow fort]]resses or digging [[snow cave]]s * [[Ice boat]]ing or [[ice sailing]] * [[Ice fishing]] * [[Ice swimming]] * [[Shinny]] * [[Snowball fight]] * [[Toboggan]]ing * Snow bowling<ref>{{cite web|title=Snow Bowling|url=https://strictlysnowgames.com/snow-bowling/|website=Strictly Snow Games|accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref> * [[Snowshoe]]ing * [[Snow golf]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Snow Golf|url=https://strictlysnowgames.com/snow-golf/|website=Strictly Snow Games|accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref>
==Notable winter sporting events== [[File:Stamps of Germany (DDR) 1968, MiNr 1339.jpg|right|thumb|upright|alt=A postage stamp with a blue background and two figure skaters skating, the date 1968 is centered on the top of the stamp along with the Olympic rings. The word "Winterspiele" is written down the right side, the words "X Olympische" are written down the left side. The number 25 is in the lower left corner and the letters "DDR" are in the lower right corner|A postage stamp issued by East Germany in 1968 in commemoration of their first Winter Olympics as an independent country under a communist regime]] * [[Winter Olympic Games]] * [[Nordic Games]] * [[World Cup (disambiguation)#Winter sports|World Cup]] * [[Arctic Winter Games]] * [[Asian Winter Games]] * [[Winter Paralympic Games]] * [[Winter Universiade]] * [[Winter Dew Tour]] * [[Winter X Games]] * [[Winter X Games Europe]]
